sen.j: 童子切（どうじぎり）は、日本の国宝に指定されている日本刀。
sen.e: Doji giri is a Japanese sword designated as a national treasure of Japan.
Dojigiri is a Japanese sword designated as a national treasure of Japan.
Dojigiri is a Japanese sword designated as a national treasure of Japan.

sen.j: 童子切安綱（どうじぎりやすつな）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also called Dojigiri Yasutsuna.
It is also called Dojigiri Yasutsuna.
It is also called Dojigiri Yasutsuna.

sen.j: 天下五剣の一つで、大包平と並んで最も優れた名刀とされている。
sen.e: It is one of five celebrated swords in the country, and said to be the most superb sword along with the Great Kanehira sword..
It is one of five celebrated swords in the country, and said to be the most superb one along with the Great Kanehira sword.
sen.cmt: 2回目の"sword"を"one"に変更余分なピリオドを削除
sen.e: It is one of five celebrated swords in the country, and said to be the most superb one along with the Great Kanehira sword.

sen.j: 現在は東京国立博物館の所蔵品となっている。
sen.e: Presently it is in the collection of the Tokyo National Museum.
Presently it is in the collection of the Tokyo National Museum.
Presently it is in the collection of the Tokyo National Museum.
Its blade length (lineal length from top of the tip to the end of the back) is 79.9cm and its warpage is 2.7cm.
Its blade length (lineal length from top of the tip to the end of the back) is 79.9cm and it is curved by 2.7cm.
sen.cmt: "its warpage is 2.7cm"を"it is curved by 2.7cm"に修正
sen.e: Its blade length (lineal length from top of the tip to the end of the back) is 79.9cm and it is curved by 2.7cm.

sen.j: 平安時代の刀工安綱の作であるとされる。
sen.e: It is believed to be a work of Yasutsuna, a sword craftsman of the Heian period.
It is believed to be a work of Yasutsuna, a sword craftsman of the Heian period.
It is believed to be a work of Yasutsuna, a sword craftsman of the Heian period.

sen.j: 清和源氏の嫡流である源頼光は、丹波国大江山に住み着いた鬼、酒呑童子の首をこの刀で切り落としたという。
sen.e: It is said that Yorimitsu MINAMOTO who belonged to the main branch of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) cut off with this sword the head of Shuten Doji, a devil who lived in Mt. Oe in Tanba Province.
It is said that MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu who is a direct descendant of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) cut off with this sword the head of Shuten Doji, a devil who lived in Mt. Oe in Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: 翻訳仕様指示書に従い、「源頼光」を左記の通り修正頼光は初代経基の孫で清和源氏3代目当主なので、そのように修正
sen.e: It is said that MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu who is a direct descendant of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) cut off with this sword the head of Shuten Doji, a devil who lived in Mt. Oe in Tanba Province.

sen.j: 童子切の名前はこの伝説に由来する。
sen.e: The name of Doji giri comes from this legend.
The name of Dojigiri comes from this legend.
The name of Dojigiri comes from this legend.

sen.j: この他にも様々なが伝わる。
sen.e: In addition to this, various anecdotes related to the sword have been known.
In addition to this, various anecdotes related to the sword have been known.
In addition to this, various anecdotes related to the sword have been known.

sen.j: 後に足利将軍家から豊臣秀吉、徳川家康、徳川秀忠、松平忠直（秀忠娘婿）に継承され、越前松平家の高田藩から津山藩に継承された。
sen.e: Later, it was inherited from Ashikaga Shogun Family to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Ieyasu TOKUNAGA, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, Tadamichi MATSUDAIRA (husband of a daughter of Hidetada) and then from Takada Domain of Matsudaira Family in Echizen Province to Tsuyama Domain.

Later, it was inherited from Ashikaga Shogun Family to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Ieyasu TOKUNAGA, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, Tadanao MATSUDAIRA (husband of a daughter of Hidetada), and then from Takada Domain of Matsudaira Family in Echizen Province to Tsuyama Domain.
sen.cmt: 「忠直」の読みを修正カンマを追加
sen.e: Later, it was inherited from Ashikaga Shogun Family to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, Ieyasu TOKUNAGA, Hidetada TOKUGAWA, Tadanao MATSUDAIRA (husband of a daughter of Hidetada), and then from Takada Domain of Matsudaira Family in Echizen Province to Tsuyama Domain.

sen.j: 津山松平家では、この童子切と稲葉郷、石田正宗の3振の名刀を家宝として伝えた。
sen.e: Matsudaira Family of Tsuyama Domain passed down the three noted swords of Doji giri, Inabago and ISHIDA Masamune as family treasures.
Matsudaira Family of Tsuyama Domain passed down the three noted swords of Dojigiri, Inabago and ISHIDA Masamune as family treasures.
Matsudaira Family of Tsuyama Domain passed down the three noted swords of Dojigiri, Inabago and ISHIDA Masamune as family treasures.

sen.j: 切れ味に関しては、江戸時代に町田長太夫という試し切りの達人が、6人の罪人の死体を積み重ねて童子切安綱を振り下ろすと、六つの死体を切断しただけではなく、刃が土台まで達した、という逸話が残っている。
sen.e: Speaking of the sharpness of the sword, a legend says that when a master of trial cutting called Chotaifu MACHIDA in the Edo period banged down Dojigiri Yasutsuna onto the dead bodies of six criminals stacked one on top of another, it not only cut through the six bodies, but its blade reached the ground.

Speaking of the sharpness of the sword, a legend says that when a master of trial cutting called Chodayu MACHIDA in the Edo period brought down Dojigiri Yasutsuna onto the dead bodies of six criminals stacked one on top of another, it not only cut through the six bodies, but its blade reached the ground.
sen.cmt: 「長太夫」の読みを修正「振り下ろす」を"banged down" から"brought down"に修正
sen.e: Speaking of the sharpness of the sword, a legend says that when a master of trial cutting called Chodayu MACHIDA in the Edo period brought down Dojigiri Yasutsuna onto the dead bodies of six criminals stacked one on top of another, it not only cut through the six bodies, but its blade reached the ground.

sen.j: 昭和21年（1946年）、津山松平家より刀剣商に売却され、紆余曲折の末、国の所有となり東京国立博物館に所蔵されている。
sen.e: In 1946 the sword was sold from Matsudaira Family of Tsuyama Domain to a sword merchant, and with some bumps and detours it passed into the state's possession and now is in the collection of the Tokyo National Museum.

In 1946, the sword was sold from Matsudaira Family of Tsuyama Domain to a sword merchant, and after twists and turns it passed into the state's possession and now is in the collection of the Tokyo National Museum.
sen.cmt: "In 1946"の後にカンマを追加"with some bumps and detours" を"after twists and turns"に変更
sen.e: In 1946, the sword was sold from Matsudaira Family of Tsuyama Domain to a sword merchant, and after twists and turns it passed into the state's possession and now is in the collection of the Tokyo National Museum.

sen.j: 尚、刀身と共に金梨地鞘糸巻拵えの陣太刀様式の外装が現存しているが、この拵えは江戸時代に製作されたものであり、作刀当初のものとは異なる。
sen.e: Furthermore, together with the sword blade there remains an exterior bodywork in jintachi style (the style of sword designed specially for use on the battle field) consisting of a Kinnashiji-painted scabbard and a Itomaki (string-wound) hilt, however these fittings were produced in the Edo period and are different from the original when the sword was made.

Furthermore, together with the sword blade there remain the scabbard and hilt of jintachi style (the style of sword designed specially for use on the battle field); a Kinnashiji-painted scabbard and a Itomaki (string-wound) hilt, however these fittings were produced in the Edo period and are different from the original when the sword was made.

sen.j: 作刀当初に収められていた拵えがどのようなものであったのかは判然としていない。
sen.e: It is unclear what the fittings looked like when the sword was made.
